Question

You are initially located at the origin on the xxx-axis. You start a random walk with an equal probability of moving left or right, one step at a time. What is the probability that you will reach point aaa before reaching point −b-b−b?

Assume aaa and bbb are natural numbers. a>1;b>1a >1; b > 1a>1;b>1

Hint

Consider the expected value of the position at the end of the game.

Answer

b/(a+b)b/(a+b)b/(a+b)

Solution

Probability

Let us assume that we stop walking the moment we reach any of aaa or −b-b−b. As we keep walking randomly, we'll eventually hit one of the two points, and the game will surely end.

Suppose PaP_aPa​ is the probability that we end at aaa, and (1−Pa)(1 - P_a)(1−Pa​) is the probability that we end with −b-b−b.

Let XXX be the position on the xxx-axis at the end of this game.

E[X]=a⋅Pa+(−b)⋅(1−Pa)E[X] = a \cdot P_a + (-b) \cdot (1 - P_a)E[X]=a⋅Pa​+(−b)⋅(1−Pa​)

Also note that the walk is symmetric (equal probability in either direction), so, logically, E[X]=0E[X] = 0E[X]=0

0=a⋅Pa−b⋅(1−Pa)0 = a \cdot P_a - b \cdot (1 - P_a)0=a⋅Pa​−b⋅(1−Pa​)

Solve to get Pa=ba+bP_a = \dfrac{b}{a + b}Pa​=a+bb​

Follow up Question

What is the expected number of steps to reach either aaa or −b-b−b?

Follow up Solution

Warning: This solution uses the knowledge of Martingales and advanced stochastic theory.

In probability theory, a Martingale is a model of a fair game where knowledge of past events does not help to predict the mean of the future winnings, and where the expected value of the next play, given all the plays so far, is the same as the present value, even though the next play could have several possible outcomes.

Formally, the sequence XnX_nXn​ is a Martinagle if:

E[Xn+1∣X1,…,Xn]=Xn{E} [X_{n+1}\mid X_{1},\ldots ,X_{n}]=X_{n}E[Xn+1​∣X1​,…,Xn​]=Xn​

Since we're conducting a random walk, where each step can either be +1+1+1 (right) or −1-1−1 (left). This type of problem can be analyzed using a Martingale approach.

Let X1,X2,X3,…X_1, X_2, X_3, \ldotsX1​,X2​,X3​,… be the position on the xxx-axis after 1,2,3…1,2,3\ldots1,2,3… steps.

Here XnX_nXn​ is a Martingale because:

E[Xn+1∣Xn]=0.5(Xn+1)+0.5(Xn−1)=XnE[X_{n+1} | X_n] = 0.5(X_{n} + 1) + 0.5(X_n - 1) = X_nE[Xn+1​∣Xn​]=0.5(Xn​+1)+0.5(Xn​−1)=Xn​

In other words, given we are standing at position XnX_nXn​, the expected value of the next step is the current value.

End Game: Let NNN = the number of steps to reach any of aaa or −b-b−b starting from position 000. We end the game when we reach either aaa or −b-b−b.

XNX_NXN​ is either aaa or −b-b−b, with probability PaP_aPa​ and (1−Pa)(1 - P_a)(1−Pa​) respectively.

Note that E[XN]=0E[X_N] = 0E[XN​]=0 because we start from 000, and all future expected values are equal to the position. This property can be used to find PaP_aPa​

0=E[XN]=a⋅Pa−b⋅(1−Pa)  ⟹  Pa=ba+b0 = E[X_N] = a \cdot P_a - b \cdot (1 - P_a)\implies P_a = \dfrac{b}{a+b}0=E[XN​]=a⋅Pa​−b⋅(1−Pa​)⟹Pa​=a+bb​

We want to calculate E[N]E[N]E[N], i.e. the number of steps taken to end the game.

Leap-of-faith: Consider the special variable Yn=(Xn2−n)Y_n = (X^2_n - n)Yn​=(Xn2​−n), what's the expected value in the next step?

E[Yn+1∣Yn]=E[Xn+12−(n+1)∣Yn]E[Y_{n+1} | Y_n] = E[X^2_{n+1} - (n+1) | Y_n]E[Yn+1​∣Yn​]=E[Xn+12​−(n+1)∣Yn​]

=0.5⋅[(Xn+1)2−(n+1)]+0.5⋅[(Xn−1)2−(n+1)]= 0.5 \cdot [(X_{n}+1)^2 - (n+1)] + 0.5 \cdot [(X_{n}-1)^2 -(n+1)]=0.5⋅[(Xn​+1)2−(n+1)]+0.5⋅[(Xn​−1)2−(n+1)]

=Xn2−n=Yn= X^2_n-n = Y_n=Xn2​−n=Yn​

This satisfies the martingale property!

Hence, at the end of the game, the expected value is: E[YN]=E[Y_N] =E[YN​]= The current value of (Xn2−n)=02−0=0(X^2_n - n) = 0^2 -0 = 0(Xn2​−n)=02−0=0 (because no moves have been made yet)

Now, we just expand E[YN]E[Y_N]E[YN​], and we can reach the result with a snap.

0=E[YN]=E[XN2−N]=E[XN2]−E[N]0 = E[Y_N] = E[X_N^2-N]= E[X_N^2] - E[N]0=E[YN​]=E[XN2​−N]=E[XN2​]−E[N]

  ⟹  0=Pa⋅a2+(1−Pa)⋅b2−E[N]\implies 0 = P_a \cdot a^2 + (1 - P_a) \cdot b^2 - E[N]⟹0=Pa​⋅a2+(1−Pa​)⋅b2−E[N]

  ⟹  E[N]=b⋅a2a+b+a⋅b2a+b\implies E[N]=\dfrac{b \cdot a^2}{a+b} + \dfrac{a\cdot b^2}{a+b}⟹E[N]=a+bb⋅a2​+a+ba⋅b2​

  ⟹  E[N]=a⋅b\implies E[N] = a\cdot b⟹E[N]=a⋅b

Hence it takes on average (a⋅b)(a\cdot b)(a⋅b) steps to end the game
